div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,576] ALEXANDRIA, Monday, August 20, 1906. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 1 May to 31 October.
Subject to the usual 25% reduction for returning.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: DES ENFANTS, LE DÉLICE!

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: The English Dally Newspaper, Established 1330 Editor and Manager - - R. Snelling Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIFF.
MONDAY, AUGUST 20, 1906.

div.head: HANDS OFF EGYPT!
div.p: To-morrow (says the "Pall Mall Gazette" of Tuesday last) his Majesty the King is to meet the German Emperor, and it is no secret that important affairs of State will occupy the attention of the two Sovereigns. First and foremost, as we must suppose, there will be the consideration of what steps it may be possible to take to assist the Tsar and the Russian Imperial family in the event of contingencies which are, at least, within the bounds of possibility. Then, presumably, they will exchange views upon the whole situation in Russia ; and, lastly, upon the somewhat delicate subject of the relations between their own respective countries. In that last connection it is instructive to note that the German Press has made, as yet, absolutely no response whatever to those overtures of friendship which have been so lavishly poured out in England during the past few months. On the contrary, the welcome—if such we may call it — extended to the British Sovereign by a Press of which the representatives were hospitably, and even enthusiastically, entertained at Windsor a few weeks ago, comes as near to positive rudeness as the circumstances permit. Of that, however, we do not complain in the least : contrariwise, we prefer it, not only because it may possibly have some effect in diminishing the volume of the cataract of soapy sentimentality which will probably overflow a certain portion of our own Press during the next few days, but also because sincerity is preferable to insincerity, and, in the present instance, may tend to awaken a good many people (who badly want awakening) to the truth about the relations, present and future, between England and Germany. What, then, is it that the German Government is looking for from this meeting of the monarchs? If we may believe the "National Zeitung," which is hardly likely to speak without know- ledge on such an occasion, while the Russian situation supplies the chief reason for the meeting, there is another. England, we are told, desires to regulate the affairs of Egypt as soon as possible, and to make the proposed settlement seem plausible in the eyes of Germany. Again, as we learn from the Berlin correspondent of the "Times," the "Deutsche Revue" discusses the Egyptian "question" from the German standpoint, and proposes that Egypt should be treated "as an object of common interest to England and Germany, and that its future should be decided between the two Powers on the basis of compensating values." In short, in this find in other matters the two nations must effect settlements "upon a footing of confiding reciprocity."

It is, no doubt, a little difficult to keep one's temper in the face of the unabashed impudence of the German assumption that there is still an "Egyptian question" which requires "settlement" with Germany or, for that matter, any other Power. Nevertheless, let us draw upon the materia medica of our philosophy for a stiff dose of patience, and try to understand what our German friends are driving at. The "Deutsche Revue" is, it must be admitted, delightfully frank. It seeks to use Lord Cromer's proposal of certain changes which would affect the status of foreigners in Egypt as a means of extorting British consent to give Germany a free hand on the shore of the Persian Gulf in the matter of the terminus of the Baghdad Railway. "For England to persist in her policy of transforming the Persian Gulf into a mare clausum Britannicum would be to throw down the gauntlet, and her persistence would compel us to meet British wishes with the same measure." In other words, Germany threatens that she will treat Egypt as she has treated Morocco, and will try to obtain "compensation for the abandonment of her rights." Now, that is a policy which no British Government can possibly tolerate. Germany's legitimate in-terests in the Nile Valley, which are purely commercial, are infinitesimally small, and unless she had interests there as great as those of France, with all the tradition of historical relations such as those of France with Egypt behind her, we could not consent to treat Egypt as "an object of common interest between England and Germany.'' There is no such "common interest," and the German assertion that there is can only he regarded as an impudent attempt to levy blackmail. The rights of all foreigners, Germans with the rest, will be as scrupulously safeguarded in the future as in the past; but Egypt is, and must remain, to all intents and purposes, a British Protectorate. Whatever be the outcome of the Baghdad Railway question, it certainly not be settled by Germany's offer to abandon "rights" in Egypt which she has never possessed. That is a consideration to be commended to the notice of those among our own people who are perpetually repeating that we have no grounds of difference with Germany. We have none; but ever since the success of the German veto upon the Anglo-French Agreement in Morocco, Germany has evidently meditating the discovery of a ground of difference with us—and that ground is Egypt. In order to foment that difference, Germany has egged on the Turk to assert himself in the Peninsula of Sinai, as he is defying France (doubtless by-the same inspiration) in the hinterland f Tripoli. So long as Germany continues to play her game of blackmail, so long will it be impossible for us to arrive at that good understanding with her which all parties in England desire. Germany must be made to realise that Egypt is a piece in the game of chess which has been definitely swept off the board by Great Britain. Wherefore, to all such proposals as are suggested by the German Press there is only ore possible answer— Hands off Egypt !"

div.head: franco-Egyptian Convention.
div.p: The decree ratifying the Commercial Con-vention between France and Egypt is published in the French "Official Journal."

div.head: Brute In Human Shape.
div.p: Advices from Maghaga report the arrest of a certain Mohamed Abou Zeid, who was interrupted in the act of burning the body of his wife, whom he had strangled.

div.head: Beyrout Family of Nine Drowned.
div.p: Among the survivors of the Sirio disaster was M. Faltat-Horat, of Beyrout, who was making the voyage with his family, consisting of ten persons, of whom he is the sole survivor.

div.head: New Quay Estate.
div.p: The next sale of the Municipal estate on the new quay will take place in October. After that date there will be auctions of this land at regular intervals until the total amount of the land fixed by the Commission for sale has been disposed of.

div.head: A Forger.
div.p: Mahmoud Hamdi el.Mutargim, who recently managed to escape from custody on the charge of forging telegraphic money orders, has been apprehended by the Cairo police. The official enquiry showed that Mahmoad Hamdi had committed forgeries to the extent of L.E. 400 during the last three months.

div.head: San Stefano Casino.
div.p: The fete de unit at San Stefano on Saturday fully realized the expectations of the large throng who filled the grounds of this popular Casino. The Bracale orchestra and the Philharmonic Band vied with each other in their musical efforts, and the evening wound up with a magnificent firework display.

div.head: A Local Composer.
div.p: Among the items of music to be played by the band of the 2nd Batt. Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers in the Esbekieh Gardens tomorrow evening. appears a march, "The Rising Nile," composed by Lieut-Colonel J. Donegan, R.A.M.C., who is at present in medical charge of the troops at Kasr e'-Nil. The arrangement for military band has been made by Bimbashi Franklin, Musical Director, Egyptian Army.

div.head: Cairo Motor Accident
div.p: The enquiry into the motor car accident which resulted in the death of a lady and injuries to Yessin Bey Mustapha, has shown that the motor car was being driven at too high a speed, and that the cart with which it collided carried no light Such, at least, was the evidence elicited from Gamila Saidla, a woman servant who was accompanying them. According to her, Dame Aisha Fadel was a close relative of the Moudir, and was a frequent caller at his house, and it was while returning to her own home that the accident took place.

div.head: Armenian Lawlessness.
div.p: There was an echo of the racial feuds in the Ottoman Empire in Alexandria yesterday afternoon, when four Armenians attacked a Greek in Mohamed-Aly square because he was selling the Alexandria Greek newspaper, "Byzantium." Our contemporary has offended Armenian susceptibilities by venturing to publish a portrait of the Orthodox Bishop of Anchialos in Eastern Roumelia. This prelate is disliked by the Armenians and so these men thrashed the Greek newsvendor and tore his papers to tatters. They were arrested and released on bail.

div.head: Taximeters for Alexandria.
div.p: A local newspaper stated that it had been decided to fit up the Alexandria cabs with taximeters. This statement is not correct, and was evidently based on the fact that a representative of a French firm of manufacturers of taximeters had submitted a proposal to the Municipality. As we understand that each taximeter costs about frs. 200, it is not likely that the proprietors of cabs will see their way to adopt it, especially as they are very pleased with the present cab tariff, which is considered most equitable for all the parties concerned.

div.head: NEW ABBAS THEATRE.
SIGNORINA LE0NI'S BENEFIT.
div.p: The final performance of The Geisha at the New Abbas Theatre on Friday night was very properly devoted to the benefit of Signs. Baldi, who, invariably welcome to Cairo audiences, has so largely contributed to the success of that piece, which has been the best received of all the company's wide repertoire. Large as the theatre is, it was almost full, and great was the applause accorded to the much feted Mimosa San when she appeared on the stage.

The Italian translation is rather a grotesque parody of the popular English play, and though the staging was certainly excellent, many of the costumes were quite incomprehensible. To see the naval officers appear in military uniform made one smile, but even greater merriment was provoked by the sight of a sailor in kilts! As regards the musical representation of the piece, there was not much fault to be found, but Mimosa San treated that pretty ''Goldfish" song with great cruelty by singing it in such painfully slow time, and we cannot understand why the finest of all the songs, 'Star of my Soul," should have been omitted. Despite these faults, however, the play went with an excellent swing, and Bignorine Baldi and Leoni, and Signori Urbano and Pirracini especially distinguished themselves in the principal characters of Mimosa San, Molly Seamore, Wun Hi, and Marquis Imaro, respectively.

div.head: DEATH OF PRINCE MOHAMED IBRAHIM.
TERRIBLE FATALITY.
Princes AUTOMOBILE COLLIDES WITH TRAIN.
div.p: LONDON, August 20.

Prince Mohamed Ibrahim, whilst motoring between Bcrnay and Cormeilles, smashed violently into a train at the level crossing between Paris and Cherbourg at 7.30 o'clock on Saturday night Both the Prince and his chauffeur are dead. According to the evidence taken, the Prince's automobile was travelling at an excessive rate of speed.
PARIS, August 18.
An automobile conveying the Egyptian Prince Ibrahim Mohamed collided with a train near Bernay. The Prince has been seriously injured. (Reuter 1
PARIS, August 18.

The automobile of Prince Mohamed Ibrahim (aged 38), cousin of H.H. the Khedive, ran into the engine of a train while crossing the Cherbourg road. It was entirely destroyed. The Prince's condition is desperate. The chauffuer has already succumbed. (Havas)
PARIS, August 19.
Prince Ibrahim Mohamed is dead. (Reuter)
PARIS, August 19.
The newspapers state that Prince Mohamed Ibrahim died in the evening. (Havas)
BERNAY, August 19.
Prince Mohamed Ibrahim succumbed after having undergone a trepanning operation. (H.)

[Bernay, where the catastrophe occurred, is on the main line to Cherbourg, between Evreux and Lisienx. It is a town of 7,966 inhabitants, and is the capital of the arrondissement of the Eure. The Chemin de Fer de l'Ouest passes through the town, and while crossing this railway line the Prince met with the accident.]

A private telegram from Cherbourg to the Daira received as we go to Press states that the Prince breathed his last at 9.30 o'clock yesterday evening. He was alone in his automobile with his chauffeur.
The Mayor of Cherbourg sent a telegram dated 4 p.m. yesterday to the Prince's Daira at Alexandria to the effect that his Highness's condition was "tres grave.''

Prince Mohamed Bey Ibrahim was the son of Prince Ibrahim Ahmed, tin cousin of the Khedive, and brother to H H. Prince Seif el Din, who is living in England. He was only 28 years of age, not 38, as stated in the Havas telegram. The Prince was married twice. Seven years ago he married Princess Fazilah, the daughter of Prince Osman Fazil. He had a son by the first wife who is now six years of age. After the death of Princess Fazilah, five years ago, his Highness married Prioress Salihab, daughter of Prince Ibrahim Hilmy, uncle of the Khedive, by whom be had two children, one a daughter who is now four years old, and the other a son, now two and a half years of age.

The Prince was the biggest landlord in the neighbourhood of Alexandria. The Alexandria Sporting Club's grounds is on his property, and he possessed a great deal of land in the city, including the large buildings in Mohamed Aly-. square where the offices of the Banco di Roma are situated. It is stated that the Prince was offered lately L.E. 2,200,000 for his estates in Alexandria and Cairo, but refused, as he wanted £3.000,000.

Prince Mohamed and his wife and children left Alexandria last month for France and took up their residence in the Prince's Parisian mansion in rae Callipert. His Highness was an ardent motorist and had already met with a terrible accident in Cairo the season before last, on the Pyramids road, when two European ladies who were with him, Mrs. Schrager and Mrs. Vuronoff, were also seriously injured.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The "Standard" of the 14th inst. contains the following announcement ' The Khedive of Egypt, who left Cowes for Ostend, is now at Spa."
No other paper states that the Khedive has visited England, so either the news is erroneous or the strictest incognito was preserved.

div.head: BAND PERFORMANCE.
div.p: By kind permission of Major C. J. L, Davidson, D.S.O., commanding, and officers, 2nd Batt. Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, the band will play the following programme of music in the Esbekieh Gardens on Tuesday from 9 to 11 p.m.
March-Heldenruf-Leitmann.
Overture--Merry Wives of Windsor—Nikola.
Walzer- Ander Schonen Blauen Donau-Strauss.
Fantasia-Maritana-Wallace.
Serenade—Siziletta-Von Blon.
Selection—Faust —Gounod.
March—The Rising Nile - Lieut Col. J. Donegan (R.A.M.C.
American Sketch —Way down in Tennessee— (Knowles.
Regimental March.
Khedivial Anthem. -God Save the King.
R. WATSON RAMSEY, Bandmaster

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner Khephren sailed from Liverpool on Friday last, and is due here about the 31st inst. with passengers, mails and general cargo.

div.head: UNREST IN THE SUDAN.
THE EXISTENCE OF FANATICISM.
div.p: In a letter which we have received from a correspondent at Port Sudan we are informed that ever since the commencement of the Akaba affair considerable unrest has been evident among the Sudanese of that district, and, our correspondent remarks, 'the existence of fanaticism thereabouts cannot be denied."

No uneasiness is said to exist among the English inhabitants, who realise that any trouble which might be brewing would very soon be discovered and that immediate steps would be taken to convince the natives of the futility of any outbreak. The couple of hundred or so Greeks in Port Sudan show, however, a most unreasonable fear of an outbreak, and scares among them are frequent.
On our part, we are convinced that Colonel Drury, Governor of that province, will be able to maintain perfect order, and we would advise our Greek friends of Port Sudan to reassure themselves.

div.head: ENGLISHMAN'S GRAVE DESECRATED.
SEARCH FOR BOOTY.
div.p: We learn from Port Sudan that Mr. Cross, an ex-soldier and foreman of works at Port Sudan, died the week before last from heat apoplexy. On the day following the burial it was found that the railings round the unfortunate man's grave had been pulled down and that the grave had been reopened. The body was found in the grave, apparently undisturbed, and it is thought that some of the Sudanese from the adjacent village had opened the grave in the hopes of finding booty.
In spite of most searching inquiries no evidence has been found to convict any of the villagers of this horrible act of desecration.

div.head: AN AWKWARD DILEMMA
RESULT OF WASH OUTS IN SUDAN.
div.p: Considerable inconvenience has been caused by the recent wash-outs which have been experienced on the Port Sudan railway. Parts of the line have been broken up and the telegraphic communication has suffered greatly.

At the time of the first of these washouts, which we reported a short while ago, Bimbashi Lord was up in the hills some eighty miles from Port Sudan and suddenly found himself altogether cut off from the nearest villages and without provisions. The telegraph line to Port Sudan being broken, the only means by which Bimbashi Lord could obtain assistance was by telegraphing to Atbara, which he did by 'tapping" a wire, and from there the message was transmitted to Cairo. From Cairo the officer's urgent summons was telegraphed to Suez, and thence to Port Sudan. In this roundabout way the unfortunate position of Bimbashi Lord was made known to his fellow-officers at Port Sudan, from where provisions and help were sent with the utmost rapidity.

div.head: TURKISH TRANSPORT'S DISTRESS-
RESCUED BY B. I. STEAMER,
div.p: Suez, Sunday.

The British India steamer Warora (Capt. A. E. Stebbing) arrived at Suez this morning from Bombay, having in tow the Turkish troopship Bars, which has on board 302 troops and 45 of a crew, from Hodeidah bound to Constantinople.

The Warora sighted the Bars 17 miles south of Ras Garib, in the Gulf of Suez, at 8.30 am. on the 18th inst. She was in distress, her engines being disabled, and she was drifting towards the shore ; in about half an hour's time she would have been on the rooks and broken up.

The commander and troops of the Turkish transport were in terrible straits, and as they possessed no flags to signal with they were seen desperately waving and crying out for assistance, their only distress signal being the ship's ensign halfmasted. The Warora, at great risk, owing to the heavy sea and strong wind, and also her close proximity to the land, approached the Bars and by mean of rockets threw lines to her. Finally she managed to get hold of the trans-port and tow her to Suez safely, after first getting the tow hawser parted, and the maneuvers had to repeated with greater risk owing to the ship drifting rapidly closer and closer to the shore.

The plan of passing ropes from one vessel to another in a heavy sea, where there is great danger attending the lowering of boats, has apparently never been attempted before, and is entirely an idea of Captain Stebbing, to whom, as well as to the officers, great credit must be given for saving the lives of so many people, who would have very likely perished were it not for the prompt assistance rendered.

div.head: GAMBLING AT SAN STEFANO
VILLA MARGHERITA RAIDED.
div.p: Early yesterday morning the Alexandria City Police, including Hacheen Bey and two detectives, made a raid on the Villa Margherita, an hotel at San 8tefano, while gambling was proceeding.
On the arrival of the police a scene of great excitement ensued, but no arrests were made. £20 and the gambling material were confiscated by the police.

div.head: THE CAPITULATIONS.
THEIR ORIGIN.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir,—A common error, shared largely by the European colonies in the Ottoman dominions, is that the Capitulations were granted only to subjects of foreign Powers. This is not so. Originally, the scope of the Capitulations comprised all non Musaulmans, resident in Turkey. If we accept the verdict of history these Capitulations were first granted, not by the Turkish Sultans, but by the Greek Emperors, to the foreign colonies within their realm, such as the Genoese, the Pisans, and the Venetians. After the Fall of Constantinople, Mahomed II., desirous of reconciling the Greeks for the loss of their political liberties, by allowing them a certain measure of their previous communal privileges, ratified the Capitulations which the Greek Lords of Byzantium had conferred upon the Latin colonies, and by a wise and masterly stroke of policy, the effects of which have lasted to this day, extended and fair proportion of those benefits to his new nor.-Mussulman subjects, chief amongst which of course at that time were the Orthodox Greeks ; and these benefits were, inter alia, that they should be governed by their own municipal laws, have their own Patriarchal Court and Justinian Code, be free of military service—in tact enjoy just as much self-government as do the foreign Colonies now with the exception of those penal and civil matters which were ultra vires of the Patriarchal Court. Moreover, the ground- work of these original Byzantine Capitulations has served as the basis of all subsequent treaties between the Ottoman Porte and Christian Princes.

An interesting and conclusive relict of this state of things is the fact that the Consul of a European Power is even to-day described in official documents, such as the exequatur, as the "Bayle," a title borrowed from that which the head of the Genoese or Venetian colony held under the Lower Empire, and which he continued to hold under the Turks.

It was this "authority and immemorial prestige" to which I referred in my letter to you of August 4 as bound to suffer by the abolition of the Capitulations, not so much from juridicial privilege as from political status, of which more anon.

Greek Orthodoxy, therefore, in common with the several other communities, Christian and Hebrew, subject to, and resident within the dominions of the Sublime Ottoman Ports, have in greater or less degrees privileges just as valid as those of the colonies of foreign Powers. In the case of the Greek community these privileges are accentuated by the fact that the Orthodox Greek Church is the Christian State religion in Turkey. The (Ecumenical Patriarch is officially just as much the head of the Greek nation as is the Sultan the Caliph of the Mohamedans, or the Pope Pontiff of the Holy Roman Empire. The Greek Church is styled the Great Church, and claims precedence in all State ceremonies, the Patriarch being alone permitted to represent the other religions communities, and as conclusive proofs of his high rank, the Sultan rises upon the entry of his (Ecumenical Holiness ; a mark of respect which is not shown to the Grand Vizier. I might enumerate various other items of Patriarchal privileges, such as the military honours, but the fact of his spiritual equality with the Sultan will suffice.
I now come to the crux of the question. Strictly speaking, and according to precedents which are indisputable, the abolition of the Capitulations in the form proposed by Lord Cromer is impossible.

Firstly, because that measure applies to a vilayet of the Ottoman Porte, and not to the whole system of the Empire; secondly, because to become effective it must require a special Irade of the Sultan; thirdly, because to conform to the spirit of impartiality with which it has been conceived, it must apply to all the non-Mussulman communities resident within this Ottoman vilayet.

The abolition of the Capitulatiols in the sense Lord Cromer has suggested by excluding the subject non Mussulman communities would render the status of those communities in Egypt null and void ; it would subject to the Egyptian authority, and not the Ottoman Porte, all those Christian and Jewish communities whose supreme authority is at Constantinople.

Thus, were the abolition realised, the Greek Patriarch of Alexandria would discover himself severed from the (Ecumenical Patriarchate of Constantinople, and, to carry the point further, would require from the Khedive, and not the Sultan, that Irade for the journey which I mentioned in my letter.

To sum up, my contentions are that the status of these non Mussulman communities of Ottoman nationality in Egypt has been over-looked in Lord Cromer's scheme; that to be thorough, that abolition must include them as well; that the effect of that measure will make the status of the Patriarchate of Alexandria an anomaly, by rendering it independent of the (Ecumenical Patriarchate without provision for a readjustment of its relations with the local Egyptian authority; that a special Irade is necessary from H.I.M. the Sultan for the abolition of the Capitulations, which would then, to be effective, have to apply to the Empire at large.

Opposition to Lord Cromer, to which a correspondent objected, although it might exist, as I know it to do, could not very well be officially expressed by a subordinate of the (Ecumenical Patriarchate of Constantinople, who alone has the prerogative to voice the views of the Orthodox Greek Church and the Greek nation.

The only solution to the difficulty would be a form of Protectorate exercised in Egypt by one or other of the Powers subject to the spiritual authority of the Orthodox Patriarch, such as Russia or Greece, and similar to that which France wields in the Levant over the Oriental Latin communities, subject to Turkey. —Yours, etc., XENOS.
Alexandria, 17th August 1906.
[P.S.—I note the quibble ie personal status is this not also included in civil law? My lawyer says it is,

div.head: ALEXANDRIA SPORTING CLUB.
AUGUST SKYE MEETING.
div.p: Saturday's Skye Meeting on the A. S. C. ground was uneventful and unexciting. There was a remarkably small attendance of the public, and few of the regular race-goers were to be seen in the enclosure, which bore a more or less deserted appearance The racing did not present any features of interest, the only close finish being afforded by the Bulkeley Plate. The betting, too, was not very animated, and on the whole the meeting met with but mediocre success. The afternoon was warm, but a cool breeze came from the sea. The band of the Royal Dublin Fusiliers helped to while away the time by a choice selection of music. The following is a description of the various events:—

SAN STEFANO PLATE of P.T. 2,500, viz: P.T. 2000 to winner and P.T. 500 to 2nd horse. For Arab ponies that have never won a race of the net value of P.T. 2,000 or more. Weight for age and inches. Distance 6 furlongs.

Chendi jumped off followed by Abou Gebal and soon got a long lead, which be maintained until reaching the 5 furlong post. Here Florist, who had been lying last, was sent to the front and came out of the cutting some lengths ahead of Chendi, who could never make up lost ground and came in second to Florist by a length. Damon (late Korosko II.) was one length behind, third. Time : 1.53.

Sinounou was the first away from a bad start, but Chendi made the running from the mile post to the 5 furlongs, when Sinounou took it up and led into the cutting with Florist. div.head: HOME CRICKET
div.p: Cricket.—Kent beat Somerset by 354 runs. Yorkshire beat Warwickshire by an innings and 90 runs.
West Indians beat Northamptonshire by 155 runs.
Hampshire beat Worcestershire by 131 runs. Notts beat Middlesex by wickets.
Lancashire beat Surrey by 6 wickets. (R.)

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: H.H. Prince Aziz Hassan arrived at Venice on Saturday week on his steam yacht Cuhona, with a party on board.
The Earl and Countess of Cromer have left London for Cromer.
H E. Hussein Pasha Fakhry, Minister of Public Works, returns here from France on September 4
Sir Mclcolm Mcllwraith, the Judicial Ad-viser, leaves England for Cairo at the end of September.
Mr. J. M. Farness, M.A., headmaster of Richmond 8chool, Yorkshire, late scholar of King's College Cambridge, has been appointed to the headmastership of Khedivieh School, Cairo.
A Reuter's telegram from London states that the writer, Miss Elizabeth Missing Sewell, is dead.
Mme Luigi Steinschoeider, who is at present at Lucerne, intends to return to Egypt this winter.
M. Aranias, professor of the Israelite Institute, at Cairo, has been arrested by the Stamboul authorities on the pretext that his passport was not in order.

On a pea travaille de toute la matinee. Les affaires se sont limitess aux memes valeurs que les jours precedents.
Quant aux fluctuations, elles indiquent en general une nouvelle baisse.

L'Union Fonciere est ferme a 6 1/4 et les Nungovich Hotels s'avancent meme a 17 1/8

div.head: Municipal te d'Alexandrie. AVIS
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjndication le dallage de diverses Ruelles.
Le cautionnement esu fixé à L.E. 40.
Le cahier des oharges est déposé au Bureau de la Voirie où il peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli oacheté à Monsieur l'Admiaistratear de la Municipalité, avant le 28 Août courant.
Elles pourront également être déposées eu séance de la Délégation, le même jour à 5h. p m.
L'enveloppe devra porter eu outre la mention "Soumission pour Dallage de diverses Ruelles."

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque, d'après les conditions du oabier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale, avant l'ouverture des offres et au pins tard le 28 Août 1906 à midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les oonditions ci-dessns sera écartée.
Le Vice-Président, (Signé) Dr. Schiess.

div.head: NOTICE.
div.p: The Administration of Wakfs is to sell by public auction, on November 21, between 9 a m. and 1 p.m., at its offices at Bab-el-Louk, Cairo, the whole lot of 12'feddans and parts situated at Manial-el R da, and belonging to the Wakf of the late Ahmed Pacha el Maneikli. The upset price per feddan is L.E. 3.000
Apply to the said office, on any day except holidays for all particulars relative to the sale. On the day appointed, applicants must present themselves at the same office, with a view to tender.
All tenders must be accompanied by a security amounting in kind equivalent to 20 per cent, of the total price of the said land.
The Administration reserves to itself the right to accept or refuse any tender.

Applicsnts whose tenders are accepted must in the coarse of ten days which are to elapse before they are notified thereof give as guarantee for the auction price of the land in question, good cultivable lands to ba valued exclusively by the Administration.

div.head: VALPARAISO EARTHQUAKE. Enormous Damage Widespread Fires Heavy Mortality

div.p: The seriousness of the Valparaiso earthquake is apparent from the records of the seismographs in the Isles of Wight, Vancouver, and elsewhere, which showed prolonged shocks lasting for 5 hours. The tides at Honolulu have been affected. The disturbance of the cable causes a lack of details, but the stories of loss of life which are current at New York are considered to be exaggerated. It is believed that the country north of Valparaiso has suffered more especially. (Reuter.)

The telegrams received here represent the condition of Valparaiso as terrible. Earthquake shocks began at 8 o'olock on Thursday evening. Many houses collapsed and fires broke out. Many persons were killed or injured. The business section has been almost entirely destroyed. A large part of the fires have been unchecked owing to the panic and gene-ai disorder. The shipping is undamaged. Belated messages from Santiago (Chili) state that many houses have collapsed. The earthquake was the severest known. The streets are filled with terrified people. (Reuter)
The damage done by the earthquake at Santiago and Valparaiso is enormous. {Havas)

According to the news received from Santiago on 18th inst., the earthquake extended over a zone of two degrees. Many public and private buildings have been greatly damaged. The losses are estimated at about 2,000,000 dollars. The mortality at Santiago is estimated roughly at about 30 and at Valparaiso at about 500 persons. Firemen from Santiago have gone to Valparaiso to quell the widespread fires. The villages of Quillota, Melipilla, San Antonio, and Llillai are in mins. Many persons have been killed or injured at Talca, Rengo, and San Fernando. Until the telegraphs have been fully restored the extent of the disaster will be uncertain. (Reuter)
The number of dead at Valparaiso in consequence of the earthquake is 5,000. (Havas)

div.head:
ENGLAND AND GERMANY.
IMPROVEMENT IN RELATIONS.

div.p: A remarkable article in the "Norddeutsche Zeitung" describes the meeting at Kronberg as another stage on the road to the improvement of the relations existing between the peoples and governments and rulers of Great Britain and Germany. It states that serious political questions were broached during the free and friendly conversations at Kronberg. The journal adds: "We knew that this was done in the desire to farther consolidate European peace." (Reuter.)

div.head:
CHURCH AND STATE IN FRANCE.
The coming conflict.

div.p: The Cabinet Council has approved the views expressed by M. Briand, who said that the Government would ignore the Encyclical and await action on the part of the clergy. It is understood that amongst the measures contemplated are included the enforcement of military service in the case of 6,000 priests who had been exempt up till now, and the suppression of the pensions. (Reuter.)
Eighteen sailors connected with the recent Baltic mutiny were condemned to death by court-martial and have been executed. (B.
Ten Kronstadt mutineers have been sen fenced to death and 122 to penal servitude. (Reuter)
Three bombs were thrown at the Governor General's carriage. He escaped unhurt, but is suffering from severe nervous prostration (F.)
Six thousand Greek families have left Bulgaria fearing outrages and have taken refuge in Adrianople. (Reuter)
Queen Alexandra has gone to Norway. (R.)

div.head: A GOOD WORD FOR THE SULTAN.
div.p: GREAT BRITAIN'S RESPONSIBILITY
BY A MEMBER OF THE CORPS DIPLOMATIQUE

To the watchful observer of affairs in the Nearer East it is not at all surprising to find that a certain amount of disturbance should have become manifest of late in the Islamic world. As yet there is no great danger to be apprehended from it, as it is more spasmodic than general, and ID existing circumstances each incident may be easily dealt with. Moreover, it is far from the desire of the sagacious ruler of Turkey to see the forces of Islam in array against those of Christianity. Relatively unimportant, however, as may be the unrest in Islam at the present time, it is likely to increase in intensity, and possibly occasion trouble later on, unless some change he brought about in the attitude of the Western world towards Turkey and its ruler, and more particularly in England. It should not be forgotten that we have more Mahomedan countries under our sway than any other Power, and therefore such trouble, if it arose, would be more likely to come our way than to move in the direction of other non- Mussulman people. Too little heed has been paid in England to the spread of education among Mahomedans and the publication of news through the medium of the native Press. Incidents are made known far and wide and commented upon, and it should surprise no one to find that exception is being taken to the constant encroachment made upon Mahomedan rights and to the treatment that the Sultan has met with at the hands of a large section of the British Press. It has, unfortunately, become a practice to speak slighting-ly of him on all occasions ; at times the Turks and their Sovereign are spoken of in language that might be much more fittingly applied to Russians and their Tsar.
Caliph and Defender of the Faith,

No one who has been privileged to witness the weekly ceremony of the "Selamlik" during j the period of the "Haj" or pilgrimage to Mecca, can have failed to note the variety of worshippers at the mosque attended by the Sultan. For several weeks strangely-garbed Orientals of every hue and cast of feature come trooping into Constantinople on their way to the Holy Cities. Their ONE object in view in passing through the city of the Sultan is to see the Caliph. Wandering about, they see the well-armed Turkish soldiers in their thousands, and the war vessels with their great gnus lying in the Golden Horn. As they pass through the Bosphorus and the Dardanelles they also note the frowning batteries and forts that guard the approaches to his capital, and proceed onward greatly impressed with the majesty and power of their religious chief. Far and wide is spread the renown of the great Caliph, as they talk over the sights they have seen at Constantinople with their less favoured co-religionists, who have had to take another route, when they meet at the Holy Cities, and to their owa people on their return to their homes. Revered as the Caliph is by so many millions of Mahomedans, is it strange that insult and ridicule in his direction should be felt and resented ?
The Advance of Islam

AS time moves onward, 'Islam' a religions force is bound to increase in strength. It is making vast strides in Africa, and in the opinion of those most competent to judge in the matter, will be the religion of that Continent. In addition to this, there will probably bemany converts made in Japan and a large addition to these already in China. If ever Pan-Islasism were to become a great disturbing force in the Empire it will be due to ourselves, to the ungenerous treatment the Sultan has received at our hands, and to the conviction being driven home to the mind of the Mahomedans that England is no longer their friend. With such an overwhelming number of Mussulmans under British rule, would it not bewail to cultivate better relations with the Sultan, more especially with the German Emperor ever seeking opportunities to pose as the friend of the Mahomedan Great mistrust, and rightfully so, is felt in England of his intentions ; but it is a great mistake to imagine that Turkey and the Sultan are entirely in his hands. Commercial advantages are obtained by Germany to our detriment because the Sultan is human, and the Emperor never fails to remind him on all occasions of his friendship and affection. Friendly vints are of frequent occurrence. The Einperor has been twice the guestof the Sultan, and not a year passes without one or two members of the family passing through Constantinople.

If our alliance with Japan (a non-Christian Power, let it be observed) has enabled us to dispense with a large portion of our naval force previously maintained in the Far East, what would not an alliance with Turkey do for us in the way of adding to our military resources for defence The Germans know this well, and therefore Teutonic intrigue is ever at work, and we are forced by it into a false position, and made to appear as if working for the destruction of Mahomedan rights, whereas in reality the Turks have no such well-wishers as we are.
Injustice to Turkey.

The Turks unfortunately can point to many instances of the gross injustice with which they are treated. It was never intended by the authors of the Berlin Treaty that a Bulgaria should be created, to become a menace to the peace of Europe. Yet we have seen how, year by year, she has steadily increased her army, without one word of remonstrance on the part of the Powers, and, in face of the commanding position she has assumed in the Balkans, the desire has been manifested in certain quarters to limit the forces of the Sultan, and to restrict their action.

The Turks have seen their kinsmen driven out of Bulgaria and Eastern Roumelia as the fruit of Christian administration, and the same process will commence in Crete, unless the Powers remain firm in their attitude, and loyally maintain the guarantees for the protection of the Mahomedan inhabitants of that island. Naturally, it is the desire of the Sultan and the Turks to restrict as much as possible foreign interference in Macedonia, seeing in it the danger of its development into autonomy, always so fatal to their interests.

It is the fashion with many English writers in the Press to speak of the neglect of British interests by our diplomatic representatives, and of the ill-will shown by the Porte. Yet it would not be difficult to show that many questions have been satisfactorily settled through the agency of our Embassy at Constantinople, more particularly by the present Ambassador.

All this is ignored by those who, while airing their jealousy of Germany, will make no effort to win the goodwill of the ruler of Turkey, just as it is forgotten how honestly he set to work after the war to restore her financial credit and pay off the old debts, and the benefits he conferred upon the "foreign bondholders" by the establishment of the Public Debt. In spite of all, it may be added, the Turks still look to us as their most disinterested friends and nothing is more desired by all patriotic Turks than to see a good and friendly understanding between the two Governments. ("Daily Mail").

div.head: THE RUSSIAN ENTENTE AND BRITISH TRADE.
div.p: Mr. Victor Marsden, who holds the place of honour in the "Fortnightly," points out the commercial benefits to ourselves which should follow a good understanding with Russia.

"New Russia will be a land of increasing needs; capital will be more evenly distributed; the peasant will be relieved of the greater part of his present crushing burden of taxation; self-respect and ambition, education and freedom of movement, will teach him a thousand needs of which he is ignorant to-day. Take, for instance, the change which has already come over the working-classes, the factory hands of Russia. These men are the leaders of the masses, precisely as the thinkers of the universities are the leaders of the middle classes. The workman of Russia has abandoned his national custom, and some of the dirty habits which accompanied it; he now dresses much the same as the self-respecting workman of Western lands; he is demanding sanitary dwellings, and leisure hours for self-improvement. The change of custom alone, when it reaches the monjik of the fields, will revolutionize the industries of Russia, which, even now, cannot supply the needs of the country except by State aid at the cost of intolerably high protective tariffs on imports."

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET.
div.p: The Money Market.

The money market continues to show ease, and the supply of gold is ample, notwithstanding the outflow for holiday purpose, which has been exceptionally large, and would appear to have reached about two millions during the last few weeks. With a bullion total 01 over £36,000,000, and a reserve of 48.73, against 46.7 a year ago, with nearly two millions en route to London, there is no ques-tion as to the Bank being in a strong position. Nor have we any reason to alter our often- expressed opinion that ease of money is likely to continue for the present, and will prove a help to the impending activity of stocks and shares. France is again trying, to employ her surplus money her?, but there are rumours of Germany wanting more gold in the autumn months.

The great activity of trade as shown in the large increase of both imports and exports is likely to keep the circulation active, but it can be safely said that never has bcoming trade demanded so little assistance from London banks or discount houses. Trade bills are now particularly plentiful, and not more than 3 to 31 per cent is obtainable for good three months' paper, while Bank Bills are a shade under 3 per cent. Such accommodation as is required by the great manufacturing centres is mainly supplied by the country banks out of the deposits in the same centres, and the enormous wealth of the country was never more clearly demonstrated than it is to day. Any slackening of trade would no doubt bring large balances for investment and employment in London, but there are no signs of this at present ; rather the contrary. Meantime, large profits are being realised in industrials, which will leave a surplus which must be invested, and will tend to raise the price of all sound securities, and possibly some of the many speculative stocks.
The Stock Markets.

This week we have seen the interesting and somewhat unusual spectacle of a revival in the stock markets after a holiday which immediately precedes the conclusion of a nineteen-day account From the outset, on Tuesday, the tone was cheerful, and this has continued throughout Several influences have conduced to this improved state of affairs. In the first place, the favourable monetary position has created a vigorous demand for gilt-edged securities, which has operated very appreciably upon other sections. Then, too, the Continental Bourses are much firmer. The strike movement in Russia appears to be less serious than first thought, and the abrupt failure of the attempt to institute a revolt against the Government is accepted as an augury for peace—for the time being, at any rate.

The splendid trade returns issued this week j have also given additional stimulus to investment business. They show that in July our exports to foreign countries exceeded all previous records, having increased by £5,621,000, while the imports are higher by £3,867,000. For the seven mouths to the end of July the aggregate gains in exports amount to no less than £30,5(9.000, and in imports to £31,299,000. These returns, added to the excellent holiday prospects, have been specially appreciated in the home railway market, which is now firmer than for some time past. Americans, on the other hand, have given away considerably.
The fact that many members are away on holiday has, of course, restricted the amount of business transacted, added to which there appears to be little stock to be had in the markets.
Consols.
Consols.

The leading feature of the week has been the active demand for gilt-edged securities, and this has put up the price ot Consols, which are particularly buoyant, at 88{ for cash, a gain on the week of 9/16. Irish Land Stock has improved to 89} the new issue to § premium and other first class stocks are proportionate^ higher.
Foreign Bonds.

The quieting-down of affairs in Russia, and the consequently steadier tone of the Paris and Berlin Bourses, has brought strength to Russian bonds, which during the week have daily advanced. The Fours are now as good as 73|, while the discount on the new loan has been reduced to 9. Last Friday we quoted the Fours at 71 J and Fives at 10 J discount. Japanese stocks are ft m, the Five- per-cents having hardened to 103 J.
Home Ralls.

This market commenced the week under the depression caused by the dividend announcements of the three leading lines, the London and North Western, the Midland, and the Great Western. At one time these dividends would have been considered very satisfactory, tot, in view of the splendid half-year which the lines have experienced, the market felt that it might reasonably expect more generous distributions than are being made. The record Board of Trade returns, and the prospects of bumper holiday traffics have, however, dispelled the weakness of this section, which daring the past two days has developed considerable strength, quite an active business having been done in nearly all the shares. In several cases yesterday there were gains of a fall point.
Americans.

There has been a considerable amount of liquidation in Wall Street since our last, and this, together with the paralysing influence of the extremely hot weather to which residents in New York have been subjected, has weakened the American market here. Nearly all along the line the shares have declined, Pennsylvanias being about the only exception. These stocks have been well supported, and the price has gained 1 and on the week at 69 J after being as high as 70 J. There has been an excellent enquiry for Canadian Police, in view of the brilliant harvest prospects. The shares are quoted tonight at 172 j, compared with 171 J last Friday. The last making-up price was 165 j.
Egyptians.

The Egyptian market has been quite active during- the past few days, and there is a good demand for the leading shares. National Bank have advanced to 26 and Agricultural Banks to 9 j—J. Delta Land and Investment are also in request, and after being as good as 3 J, are now easier at 3 J. Egyptian Estates are firm at 1}-ft. There has been a good business done in Daira Sugar at prices between 5 and 5 Daira Sanieh have not yet felt the better tone, and are ubi.i at 16 J, and the Deferred at 97 nominal. Delta Preference Bearer are also unmentioned at about 11 The 4% Debentures of the latter are still wanted at 102. Bank of Abyssinia are a bad market, with absolutely no support, the prices being distinctly fl it at 1 {— J discount. Union Fonqiere are firmer at 6 J— and Land Bank of Egypt at 8 j—J. There is no change in Corporation of Western Egypt at | premium, and Salt and Soda at 1 and Egyptian Markets at 1 } are without any transactions. Khedivial Mail are 1 J—j.
Mining.

Commencing with Rhodesians, the South African market has received considerable attention. When it is remembered that this is the eve of the carry-over, this marked revival is all the more remarkable, and is very welcome as an augury of better things to come. There has been a very active demand for Tanganyikas, also for Zambesi and Bankets, the strength of these and other leading Rhodesian shares being partly attributed to a fuller realisation by investors of the wonderfal potentialities for the development of the mining districts of Rhodesia contained in the late Mr. Beit's munificent gift to the Cape-Cairo Railway. It most be apparent to the meanest understanding that the results which must inevitably follow such an opening up of the country will he enormous, and in view of this fact far-seeing investors will not be slow to avail themselves of the present low price of South African mining shares. Yesterday Kaffirs participated in the activity, and they have continued firm to-day. Rand Mines have improved to 6j and East Rands to4j. Egyptian mining shares have kept steady. Egyptian Mines have been very firm, the price having advanced to 4s. 6d. United Africans have gained J at 1 J. Nile Valleys are unchanged at 58. 6d. and Options at 1 J.
